description:
Acytostelium subglobosum LB1 is a species of cellular slime mold, also known as a social amoeba, belonging to the phylum Amoebozoa. It is a eukaryotic, unicellular organism that exhibits a unique life cycle involving both solitary and social stages.

The vegetative stage of Acytostelium subglobosum LB1 is characterized by individual amoeboid cells that feed on bacteria and other microorganisms in their environment. These amoeboid cells are capable of movement and chemotaxis, allowing them to locate and consume their prey.

Under certain environmental conditions, such as nutrient depletion or overcrowding, the individual amoeboid cells of Acytostelium subglobosum LB1 can aggregate and form a multicellular fruiting body. This fruiting body consists of a stalk, which supports a spore-bearing structure called a sorocarp. The spores produced within the sorocarp can then be dispersed, allowing the organism to colonize new environments.

Acytostelium subglobosum LB1 is a model organism for the study of cellular differentiation, morphogenesis, and the evolution of multicellularity, as it exhibits a complex life cycle that involves the transition from solitary to social behavior.
